newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean won closes down, but up from opening.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean won closes down, but up from opening.

text.p: The South Korean won finished Tuesday's trading lower than the previous day, but higher than the opening level, dealers said.
The won fell sharply at opening on the Japanese yen's drop against the U.S. dollar on world markets, but stop-loss dollar selling pushed up the won later in the day, they said.
It ended at 894.00, against Monday's close of 893.10. It opened at 896.00 and moved between 892.70 and 897.50.
Dealers said traders would not remain long with dollars when the dollar was unlikely to sharply rise in the near future.
But dealers said the basic sentiment remained strong towards the dollar due to the country's huge current account deficit and the Japanese yen's weakness against the U.S. unit.
"Today's trend was in contrast to underlying factors," said a domestic bank dealer. "But there's a possibility for the dollar to sharply rebound if the dollar falls further."
Dealers expected the won's base mid-rate for Wednesday to be pegged at 894.20, compared with 895.00 won for Tuesday.
